docs.lead_paragraph: A study showing that pain administered in infancy can permanently rewire the nervous system in rats may have implications for human infants undergoing painful medical procedures, researchers are reporting today. Rats whose feet were made sore for a few days when they were infants ended up hypersensitive to pain as adults, the researchers found. The finding, they said, could be worrisome in the case of babies and premature infants in intensive care units who are repeatedly stuck with needles and subjected to other painful tests and treatments.

headline.main: Babies' Pain Has Long Effect, Study Hints

docs.abstract: Study showing that pain administered in infancy can create permanent hypersensitivity in rats may have implications for human infants who undergo painful medical procedures; research led by Dr Maryann Ruda is published in journal Science (M)
docs.snippet: A study showing that pain administered in infancy can permanently rewire the nervous system in rats may have implications for human infants undergoing painful medical procedures, researchers are reporting today.    Rats whose feet were made sore  for...

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has rejected the Giuliani administration's efforts to move ahead with its sweeping welfare-to-work project, ruling that the city cannot turn any more of its welfare centers into job centers, which discourage the poor from seeking public assistance. In the ruling, made public yesterday, the judge found no reliable evidence that the city had stopped illegally denying emergency food stamps, Medicaid and cash aid to eligible applicants -- like pregnant women with young children and disabled, homeless adults -- and refused to lift the temporary ban he imposed last year on the conversion of welfare offices.

headline.main: Judge Rules Against City On Welfare

docs.abstract: Federal Judge William H Pauley III rejects Giuliani administration's efforts to move ahead with its sweeping welfare-to-work project, ruling that New York City cannot turn any more of its welfare centers into job centers, which discourage poor from seeking public assistance; rules that he found no reliable evidence that city had stopped illegally denying emergency food stamps, Medicaid and cash aid to eligible applicants (M)
